abstract.text: A view that uses the Move, Exercise, and Stand activity rings to display data from a HealthKit activity summary object.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: shows how the rings can display a summary view of the user’s activity.
The activity ring view always appears as a black rectangle with red, green, and blue concentric rings. The rings are centered in the view and are sized to fit the available space (see

The rings have two different ways to display a lack of data. One indicates that the activity summary is missing, and the other indicates that the activity summary’s values are set to zero. If the ring has a
property, the rings appear empty. Use this to indicate that there is no summary data available for the specified day (for example, dates in the future).

If the summary has zero-valued quantities set for its value properties,  the ring displays a dot at the top of the ring. Use this to indicate that the user has not yet burned any active calories, exercised, or earned any stand hours for the specified day.
To display activity summary data from the HealthKit store, use an
object. You can also instantiate and display your own
To display data for a ring, the
quantity for both the corresponding value property and the goal property (see <doc:hkactivityringview).
The activity ring view colors a percentage of each ring based on these properties, as shown here:

code: ring percent = value property quantity / goal property quantity

abstract.text: Access and share health and fitness data while maintaining the user’s privacy and control.
An object that contains the move, exercise, and stand data for a given day.
The amount of active energy the user burned during the specified day.
The user’s daily goal for active energy burned.
The amount of time that the user has spent exercising during the specified day.
The user’s daily exercise goal.
The number hours in the specified day during which the user has stood and moved for at least a minute per hour.
The user’s daily goal for stand hours.
A query for reading activity summary objects from the HealthKit store.
Create and run activity summary queries.
Display user interface that enables a person to view and interact with their health data.
A view that uses the Move, Exercise, and Stand activity rings to display data from a HealthKit activity summary object.
The active summary displayed by the activity ring view.
Sets the activity summary displayed by the activity ring view.
An object that manages the content for a rectangular area on the screen.
Methods your app can implement to respond to layer-related events.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that an object adopts to create a bar object in your app.
Methods that associate a unique identifier with elements in your user interface.
An interface that provides a source for shareable content to fulfill user requests to share current content.
A collection of methods that gives you access to the appearance proxy for a class.
A protocol that a class must adopt to allow appearance customization using the [`UIAppearance`](doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIAppearance) API.
A set of methods for converting between different frames of reference on a screen.
A set of methods that can make a custom object eligible to participate in UIKit Dynamics.
A set of methods that define the focus behavior for a branch of the view hierarchy.
An object that can become focused.
The container responsible for providing geometric context to focus items within a given focus environment.
Methods that provide details about how to display your custom content in the large content viewer.
The interface that determines whether a responder object supports paste configuration.
A type that can be an anchor for a popover presentation controller.
A set of standard methods that apps can adopt to support editing.
A set of methods that makes the iOS interface environment available to your app.
The protocol you adopt to restore an object’s state from a user activity.
A type that calls your code in reaction to changes in the trait environment.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
